group_1.textRight: Yes.
When Tart became a Magical Girl, she and Liz left@her hometown.
This was her first destination.
...Huh?
Elisa? And Melissa?
Of course we do!
My squadron and I...
...fought alongside you and La Pucelle...
...to save France!

group_1.textLeft: My apologies. I hadn't recognized we were@comrades.

group_1.textRight: Our encampment is just ahead, if you'd like to stay@with us.
Our campaign against England continues,
but for tonight...we'll be taking a rest.
Elisa...!

group_1.textLeft: Yes. We graciously accept your offer.

group_1.textRight: We've been on a journey to places where Tart's―
No, La Pucelle's presence still lingers.
...One of the very first people who treated La Pucelle@as not just a mere girl,
but a holy lady, was Lord Baudricourt, the captain@of Vaucouleurs.
After meeting her, he arranged for her to be@escorted to the Palace of Chinon.
There, she held an audience with His Majesty@Charles, who was then the Dauphin.

group_1.textLeft: That was where she and I first met.

group_1.textRight: One of the squires who escorted her there, Jean,@is from my hometown.
He used to tell me stories about La Pucelle...
...like how she saved his life, even though he was@the one who was supposed to protect her!

group_1.textLeft: What other stories do you remember?

group_1.textRight: Well...

group_1.textLeft: ...Tart always wanted peace, and never war?

group_1.textRight: Yeah. All she really wanted was to go back to being@an ordinary village girl.
She said she was more comfortable with a needle@and thread than a sword.

group_1.textLeft: ...That reminds me of a story I heard.
Apparently it came from Sir Bâtard Jean, another@one of La Pucelle's former comrades-in-arms.
It was about a dream La Pucelle had one day, about@the time when her sister was still alive...
She dreamt of the days when they went to church@and chased sheep around.

group_1.textRight: I'm sure it's true.
Every day, the people of France long to return to@those times...
That's why Tart kept fighting.

group_1.textLeft: ...She knew she could never go back to those days.
But even so, she kept fighting, not for her sake, but@for everyone else's...

group_1.textRight: Yes...

group_1.textLeft: I'm glad we met. Thank you for your time, and for@sharing your stories.

group_1.textRight: It was a pleasure to meet you as well.
The war against England still rages...
But as the heirs of La Pucelle's resolve...
We shall march on!
